perturbation.original_text:
6.6. Effect of Termination.  
(a) Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and 
Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed ninety (90) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution. 
Upon expiration of this Agreement or such 90-day period, (i) all rights granted to Licensee under this Agreement with respect to the Licensed 
Domain Names and Licensed Content shall immediately cease, and (ii) Licensee shall immediately discontinue all use of the Licensed Domain 
Names and Licensed Content.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.6. Effect of Termination.  
(a) Upon termination (but not expiration) of this Agreement for any reason, Licensee shall be entitled to use the Licensed Domain Names and 
Licensed Content for a limited period of time, not to exceed thirty (30) days, during which it shall diligently work to transition to another solution. 
Upon expiration of this Agreement or such 30-day period, (i) all rights granted to Licensee under this Agreement with respect to the Licensed 
Domain Names and Licensed Content shall immediately cease, and (ii) Licensee shall immediately discontinue all use of the Licensed Domain 
Names and Licensed Content.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a 90-day period for transitioning after termination, while the changed text reduces this period to 30 days. This creates a direct contradiction regarding the allowed transition period, leading to uncertainty about enforcement.

perturbation.original_text:
10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that 
should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within seven (7) days after its 
receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text:
10.1. Taxes. Each Party shall be responsible for taxes that should be borne by it in accordance with applicable Law. If any Party pays any taxes that 
should have been borne by the other Party in accordance with Law, such other Party shall reimburse such Party within thirty (30) days after its 
receipt of documentation evidencing such tax payment so incurred by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires reimbursement of taxes within seven days, while the changed text extends this period to thirty days. This creates an in-text contradiction, leading to uncertainty regarding the deadline for reimbursement of tax payments.

perturbation.original_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.  
(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision 
of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of thirty (30) days after 
receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such thirty (30) 
day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such thirty (30) day period, the Parties shall negotiate a reasonable additional time to 
cure.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.3. Termination for Breach.  
(a) By Licensor. Licensor may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the Licensee is in material default or breach of any provision 
of this Agreement, and, if such default or breach is capable of cure, such default or breach continues uncured for a period of fifteen (15) days after 
receipt of written notice thereof; provided, however, that in the event that the Licensee has in good faith commenced cure within such fifteen (15) 
day period, but cannot practically complete such cure within such fifteen (15) day period, the Parties shall negotiate a reasonable additional time to 
cure.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for a 30-day cure period for a material breach, while the changed text reduces this period to 15 days. This creates a direct conflict regarding the timeframe allowed to remedy a breach before termination, causing uncertainty in enforcement.
